item.title: Marvel Rivals’ Season 3 Wolverine Skin Zigged When It Should Have Zagged
item.description:
Marvel Rivals ’ new era begins this upcoming weekend with the launch of Season 3, The Abyss Awakens. It’ll be fascinating to see how well-paced Marvel Rivals ’ new seasonal structure is. And, with two themes shared across both months, it is tremendously exciting to learn which characters’ cosmetics belong to which. For example, it would’ve been one of the worst oversights imaginable if Marvel Rivals wasn’t taking advantage of a symbiote-themed season by embracing Spider-Man wholly with a black symbiote suit of his own, and he’s thankfully receiving one in the Season 3 BattlePass, titled “Powers of the Phoenix.”

But while symbiote skins could be adaptable to nearly any character with at least somewhat predictable designs—Squirrel Girl’s bushy, symbiote-mouthed tail notwithstanding—Phoenix-themed skins are arguably more creatively challenged. Phoenix skins have been confirmed for Black Panther, Wolverine, Emma Frost, Black Widow, Namor, Iron Fist, and Magik as they’re all represented in a gallery card panel, while Blade and Venom are also shown to receive one of their own. However, while Wolverine receiving a Phoenix-themed costume is terrific, it hopefully won’t mean that Marvel Rivals has denied him a symbiote costume.

Marvel Rivals’ Symbiote Theme Shares Season 3 with the Phoenix Force

Wolverine having a Phoenix-themed skin—cheekily dubbed ‘Weapon PhoeniX’—in the BattlePass is one thing, but for it to be depicted in a gallery card is another entirely. Indeed, Marvel Rivals ’ gallery cards supply a significant amount of the game’s lore, and the artwork illustrated in each panel typically tells part of a larger story told within each serial. Marvel Rivals currently features three comic book serials as a new serial is launched for each season:

  • Vol. 0, ‘Dooms’ Rise’
  • Vol. 1, ‘Eternal Night Falls’
  • Vol. 3, ‘Hellfire Gala’

Each serial is embedded in Marvel Rivals ’ ongoing lore and narrative. Therefore, it’s fair to presume that any character donning a Phoenix-themed skin in Season 3’s serial will have that costume be relevant to the story.

That doesn’t necessarily mean characters who receive Phoenix-themed skins can’t have symbiote-themed skins, either in Season 3, Season 3.5, or at some point in the future, but it may need to be woven into the lore somehow for such a costume debut to make sense. Wolverine isn’t obligated to have a symbiote-themed costume, for instance, and yet not having one would be a missed opportunity when one of his most iconic video game appearances featured a neat symbiote look for the character in Spider-Man: Web of Shadows .

Marvel Rivals Has a Rare Opportunity to Reference Spider-Man: Web of Shadows

Spider-Man: Web of Shadows may not be the most widely beloved Spider-Man game for several reasons. That said, Wolverine plays a pivotal role as a side character, and his black-and-yellow symbiote visage endures as one of the game’s most memorable pieces of iconography.

If nothing else, Marvel Rivals giving Wolverine a symbiote skin could be a fun way to reference Spider-Man: Web of Shadows , even if that might seem like a random game to cite inspiration from for a Marvel Rivals skin. Marvel Rivals has taken inspiration from Marvel’s Spider-Man 2 for a nearly identical adaptation of a Spider-Man skin, though, and so it wouldn’t be out of the realm of possibility to imagine a Spider-Man: Web of Shadows -inspired costume, especially when its Symbiote Wolverine is so profoundly venerable.

In the meantime, many characters may fall by the wayside and not even receive a new Phoenix- or symbiote-themed skin this season, whereas some characters might get a symbiote skin and not a Phoenix skin, or vice versa. Marvel Rivals can certainly be distinct by sticking with a Phoenix skin for Wolverine, to be fair, yet a symbiote costume would be terrific, even if it doesn’t adapt the same design from Spider-Man: Web of Shadows .

10 Images

item.title: The Sims 4: Satisfaction Point Cheats
item.description:
While players' main objective in The Sims 4 is to take care of their Sims Needs, there are other objectives that they can complete to improve their Sim's happiness and grant them unique perks and items. Players can fullfil their Sims' Wants and work towards their lifetime Aspirations to receive Satisfaction Points, which can be exchanged in the Rewards Store for potions and powerful traits.

While gamers can acquire Satisfaction Points as they play The Sims 4 , they can make their life easier by cheating for more points. This guide shows players how they can cheat for more Satisfaction Points in The Sims 4 .

How to Get More Satisfaction Points in The Sims 4 (With Cheats)

Satisfaction Points Cheat Codes

In order to cheat for more Satisfaction Points, players will first have to turn on cheats. Gamers can enable cheats in The Sims 4 by opening the cheat console and inputting the code "testingcheats on" or "testingcheats true".

Once they've done this, they switch control to the Sim that they'd like to attribute the Satisfaction Points to. Lastly, they have to open the cheat console once again and input the following code:

  • sims.give_satisfaction_points [number]

The [number] must be replaced by the number of Satisfaction Points that players would like the Sim to receive. For example, if players would like to get 4,000 Satisfaction Points so they can get the Hardly Hungry reward trait, they must insert "sims.give_satisfaction_points 4000" onto the cheat console.

After increasing the number of Satisfaction Points available to a Sim, players can open the Rewards Store, which is located in the Aspirations panel, and purchase whichever rewards they'd like, ranging from useful traits to helpful potions.

The maximum number of Satisfaction Points that a Sim can have is 2,147,483,647.

item.title: Red Dead Redemption 2 Just Got Its Best Update in Years, and the Best Part Is It's Free
item.description:
A new Red Dead Online update appeared out of the blue in July 2025, marking the game's first major content drop in years. The release caught many fans off guard and even sparked speculation that Rockstar may have additional plans for Red Dead Redemption 2 and its online component in the near future.

Rockstar supported its live-service Western game with regular content updates for nearly four years after its 2018 launch. In July 2022, the company announced it was winding down development on Red Dead Online and no longer planned to release major updates. This decision came as Grand Theft Auto 6 was already deep into development, with Rockstar presumably aiming to reallocate more staff to the project.

Three years later, it would appear that Rockstar's definition of a "major" update may not align with that of its player base, as Red Dead Online has just recently received a fairly substantial patch at the beginning of July 2025. Called Strange Tales of the West, the update introduces four additional Telegram missions for players to undertake, in addition to kicking off a new event with limited-time challenges and rewards. Best of all, it's entirely free.

Red Dead Online's New Mission Is a Throwback to Undead Nightmare

The new missions are presented as supernatural investigations commissioned by one Theodore Levin, an author interested in unexplained phenomena. The standout among them is "Strange Tales of the Plague," which sends players into a zombie-infested version of Armadillo, a small settlement in the Cholla Springs region of New Austin. Both the premise and execution of this mission are reminiscent of Red Dead Redemption 's Undead Nightmare, which is still widely regarded as one of the best expansions Rockstar ever made.

Rockstar Teasing More Red Dead Online Content

The inclusion of zombie-themed content has sparked some isolated calls on social media for Red Dead Redemption 2 to receive its own version of Undead Nightmare. But six years after the game’s launch, such a development appears highly unlikely. Red Dead Online , however, now seems all but certain to receive additional content, with the strongest indication being the title used in some of Rockstar’s promotional materials for the July 2025 update: "Strange Tales of the West Volume 1 ."

When exactly Volume 2 might arrive is unclear. Rockstar’s renewed focus on Red Dead Online comes as a surprise, especially given recent reports that the studio has shifted into an all-hands-on-deck mode for GTA 6 . In a broader context, one possible explanation for the new content may be the rumored next-gen patch for Red Dead Redemption 2 and RDO , which has supposedly been in the works for a while now and may materialize in the second half of 2025, according to a May report by Gamereactor.

item.title: Game Publisher Group Says Stop Killing Games Movement's Proposals Would 'Curtail Developer Choice'
item.description:
A group of European publishers is pushing back against the ongoing "Stop Killing Games" movement, suggesting that the initiative against live-service games could severely hinder some developers. Game preservation has been a hot-button issue for many fans and developers as games and studios move towards digital-only and live-service games as their main focus. Many have expressed their worries about whether online-only games can be properly preserved or if some games, like Ubisoft's The Crew , will be lost forever once their servers go down. Now, a new movement aimed at preserving online games is gaining major steam.

The "Stop Killing Games" movement has gained major notoriety throughout recent weeks, with the game preservation movement seeing a surge in support. The campaign, founded by popular gaming YouTuber Ross Scott, has quickly amassed over a million signatures from fans concerned about gaming's future. The initiative has even shared some of its lofty goals for the campaign, planning to bring the movement either to the UK's Parliament or the European Commission after gaining enough signatures. However, some European publishers are now pushing back against the movement's ideals.

European Publisher Group Pushing Back Against "Stop Killing Games" Movement

As reported by PCGamer, European publisher group Video Games Europe is now speaking out against the burgeoning "Stop Killing Games" movement. In an official statement, the group expressed its own stance on the cancellation of live-service games, suggesting that sunsetting games is a necessary option for many studios from a financial standpoint. The group also expressed the importance of privacy for user data and removing illegal content, with a game's studio being liable for private servers. The group also claimed the movement would make live-service games "prohibitively expensive" to make.

The debate about live-service games has long been one of the biggest talking points in modern gaming, as many studios have moved more towards the online-only model. Many of gaming's most popular modern games have opted for a live-service model, with games like Genshin Impact and Wuthering Waves seeing massive success. Online game modes have also become a mainstay of modern shooters and sports games, often seeing their online services shuttered just a few years after launch.

The movement for game preservation has often seen many developers looking to make their older games more readily accessible on modern platforms. Games like Capcom Fighting Collection 2 have sought to make older games available on modern consoles, making often rare and highly sought-after games easily accessible. Nintendo's "Switch Online" service also offers a variety of older Nintendo games for subscribers, featuring classic games from both the developer's home consoles and handhelds. Game preservation will likely continue to be a major debate, as fans look to prevent increasingly online games from being lost forever.

item.title: Silent Hill f Appears Unrelated to Previous Games, and It Should Stay That Way
item.description:
If Silent Hill f didn’t have ‘ Silent Hill ’ in the name, it could probably get away with not being a Silent Hill game at all. Silent Hill f ’s immediately obvious distinction is its unique and unprecedented setting of the secluded town of Ebisugaoka in 1960s Japan, which seems like it couldn’t be taking place farther than Silent Hill ’s titular, rural tourist town in Maine, the iconic American locale that is typically where the franchise resides. Moreover, Silent Hill f ’s emphasis seems to be less on its chosen setting and more on its lead protagonist, not unlike Silent Hill 2 , and f is arguably right to make such distinguishing strides.

Silent Hill f’s Novelty is a Blessing and a Curse

Silent Hill ’s whole catalog is a series of hits and misses, with its biggest hits landing early in the franchise and its biggest misses following them. Its enduring popularity as an IP is frankly bewildering when many other horror IPs have launched since and not met nearly the same highs, and, before Bloober’s Silent Hill 2 remake, it was unclear whether Silent Hill was going to be shelved indefinitely, let alone if Konami or any development studio should bother withdrawing it from the shelf at all.

That’s why, even if f could realistically be its own IP, it’s arguably largely in Silent Hill ’s favor for f to afford it a new direction. Silent Hill f ’s originality allows it to potentially dodge the need for lore tethers if it wishes to avoid them, for instance, and can be the first in a bold line of games that basically rewrite what is known about Silent Hill canon.

Of course, f drawing itself away from everything and anything ‘ Silent Hill ’ would also beg the question of what makes it inherently a Silent Hill game, then, or why it deserves to carry the legacy of one of the most influential psychological/survival horror progenitors of all time. Indeed, Silent Hill f may be a wonderful blank canvas at best and a jarring excuse for a lore rewrite or course correction at worst, but its lack of any tenable or identifiable connections to the series’ past may serve it best.

f Being ‘Silent Hill’ in Nothing But Name Can Be a Boon

To say that the Silent Hill franchise is maligned and divisive would be a gross understatement. That said, the series’ horizons have been far brighter since Bloober snuffed out any and all paranoia that it would fumble the Silent Hill 2 remake.

Early responses to Bloober remaking Silent Hill 2 were met with unease and skepticism for multiple reasons, least of all being that Silent Hill 2 is the most revered Silent Hill game to date. Silent Hill 2 ’s remake is not only a terrific survival horror game but one of the best Silent Hill games ever now, regardless of how low that bar is and was, and the recent announcement of Bloober remaking the original Silent Hill has consequently been met with a ton of excitement and good faith.

Likewise, Silent Hill f is alluring because of how alien it is with regard to the rest of the franchise. To be fair, Silent Hill f ’s gameplay does already look strikingly similar to that of Silent Hill 2 ’s remake. This’ll be agreeable if combat is paced well alongside puzzles and exploration, but Silent Hill f ’s greatest advantage is still the fact that it’ll present new lore and imagery in what will undoubtedly be the single most unique Silent Hill game, and Silent Hill: Townfall following it will hopefully be representative of the series finding its legs in a modern horror era to swiftly and successfully expunge its past blemishes.
